segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes what AppLocker is and how its features differ from Software Restriction Policies.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes what AppLocker is and how its features differ from Software Restriction Policies.

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes what AppLocker is and how its features differ from Software Restriction Policies.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes what AppLocker is and how its features differ from Software Restriction Policies.

segment.source: AppLocker advances the app control features and functionality of Software Restriction Policies.
segment.target: AppLocker advances the app control features and functionality of Software Restriction Policies.

segment.source: AppLocker contains new capabilities and extensions that allow you to create rules to allow or deny apps from running based on unique identities of files and to specify which users or groups can run those apps.
segment.target: AppLocker contains new capabilities and extensions that allow you to create rules to allow or deny apps from running based on unique identities of files and to specify which users or groups can run those apps.

segment.source: Control the following types of apps: executable files (.exe and .com), scripts (.js, .ps1, .vbs, .cmd, and .bat), Windows Installer files (.mst, .msi and .msp), and DLL files (.dll and .ocx), and packaged apps and packaged app installers (appx).
segment.target: Control the following types of apps: executable files (.exe and .com), scripts (.js, .ps1, .vbs, .cmd, and .bat), Windows Installer files (.mst, .msi and .msp), and DLL files (.dll and .ocx), and packaged apps and packaged app installers (appx).

segment.source: Define rules based on file attributes derived from the digital signature, including the publisher, product name, file name, and file version.
segment.target: Define rules based on file attributes derived from the digital signature, including the publisher, product name, file name, and file version.

segment.source: For example, you can create rules based on the publisher attribute that is persistent through updates, or you can create rules for a specific version of a file.
segment.target: For example, you can create rules based on the publisher attribute that is persistent through updates, or you can create rules for a specific version of a file.

segment.source: Assign a rule to a security group or an individual user.
segment.target: Assign a rule to a security group or an individual user.

segment.source: For example, you can create a rule that allows all Windows processes to run except Registry Editor (Regedit.exe).
segment.target: For example, you can create a rule that allows all Windows processes to run except Registry Editor (Regedit.exe).

segment.source: Use audit-only mode to deploy the policy and understand its impact before enforcing it.
segment.target: Use audit-only mode to deploy the policy and understand its impact before enforcing it.

segment.source: The import and export affects the entire policy.
segment.target: The import and export affects the entire policy.

segment.source: For example, if you export a policy, all of the rules from all of the rule collections are exported, including the enforcement settings for the rule collections.
segment.target: For example, if you export a policy, all of the rules from all of the rule collections are exported, including the enforcement settings for the rule collections.

segment.source: If you import a policy, all criteria in the existing policy are overwritten.
segment.target: If you import a policy, all criteria in the existing policy are overwritten.

segment.source: Streamline creating and managing AppLocker rules by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets.
segment.target: Streamline creating and managing AppLocker rules by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets.

segment.source: AppLocker helps reduce administrative overhead and helps reduce the organization's cost of managing computing resources by decreasing the number of help desk calls that result from users running unapproved apps
segment.target: AppLocker helps reduce administrative overhead and helps reduce the organization's cost of managing computing resources by decreasing the number of help desk calls that result from users running unapproved apps

segment.source: For information about the application control scenarios that AppLocker addresses, see AppLocker policy use scenarios.
segment.target: For information about the application control scenarios that AppLocker addresses, see AppLocker policy use scenarios.

segment.source: What features are different between Software Restriction Policies and AppLocker?
segment.target: What features are different between Software Restriction Policies and AppLocker?

segment.source: The following table compares AppLocker to Software Restriction Policies.
segment.target: The following table compares AppLocker to Software Restriction Policies.

segment.source: File hash, path, certificate, registry path, and Internet zone
segment.target: File hash, path, certificate, registry path, and Internet zone

segment.source: Wizard to create multiple rules at one time
segment.target: Wizard to create multiple rules at one time

segment.source: The following table compares the application control functions of Software Restriction Policies (SRP) and AppLocker.
segment.target: The following table compares the application control functions of Software Restriction Policies (SRP) and AppLocker.

segment.source: SRP policies can be applied to all Windows operating systems beginning with Windows XP and Windows Server 2003.
segment.target: SRP policies can be applied to all Windows operating systems beginning with Windows XP and Windows Server 2003.

segment.source: AppLocker policies apply only to those supported operating system versions and editions listed in Requirements to use AppLocker.
segment.target: AppLocker policies apply only to those supported operating system versions and editions listed in Requirements to use AppLocker.

segment.source: But these systems can also use SRP.
segment.target: But these systems can also use SRP.

segment.source: Use different GPOs for SRP and AppLocker rules.
segment.target: Use different GPOs for SRP and AppLocker rules.

segment.source: SRP allows users to install applications as an administrator.
segment.target: SRP allows users to install applications as an administrator.

segment.source: AppLocker policies are maintained through Group Policy, and only the administrator of the device can update an AppLocker policy.
segment.target: AppLocker policies are maintained through Group Policy, and only the administrator of the device can update an AppLocker policy.

segment.source: AppLocker permits customization of error messages to direct users to a Web page for help.
segment.target: AppLocker permits customization of error messages to direct users to a Web page for help.

segment.source: SRP policies are updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in or the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).
segment.target: SRP policies are updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in or the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).

segment.source: AppLocker policies are updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in or the GPMC.
segment.target: AppLocker policies are updated by using the Local Security Policy snap-in or the GPMC.

segment.source: AppLocker supports a small set of PowerShell cmdlets to aid in administration and maintenance.
segment.target: AppLocker supports a small set of PowerShell cmdlets to aid in administration and maintenance.

segment.source: To manage SRP policies, SRP uses Group Policy within a domain and the Local Security Policy snap-in for a local computer.
segment.target: To manage SRP policies, SRP uses Group Policy within a domain and the Local Security Policy snap-in for a local computer.

segment.source: To manage AppLocker policies, AppLocker uses Group Policy within a domain and the Local Security Policy snap-in for a local computer.
segment.target: To manage AppLocker policies, AppLocker uses Group Policy within a domain and the Local Security Policy snap-in for a local computer.

segment.source: Rules for blocking malicious scripts prevents all scripts associated with the Windows Script Host from running, except those that are digitally signed by your organization.
segment.target: Rules for blocking malicious scripts prevents all scripts associated with the Windows Script Host from running, except those that are digitally signed by your organization.

segment.source: AppLocker rules can control the following file formats: .ps1, .bat, .cmd, .vbs, and .js.
segment.target: AppLocker rules can control the following file formats: .ps1, .bat, .cmd, .vbs, and .js.

segment.source: In addition, you can set exceptions to allow specific files to run.
segment.target: In addition, you can set exceptions to allow specific files to run.

segment.source: SRP can prevent all Windows Installer packages from installing.
segment.target: SRP can prevent all Windows Installer packages from installing.

segment.source: It allows .msi files that are digitally signed by your organization to be installed.
segment.target: It allows .msi files that are digitally signed by your organization to be installed.

segment.source: The Windows Installer rule collection is a set of rules created for Windows Installer file types (.mst, .msi and .msp) to allow you to control the installation of files on client computers and servers.
segment.target: The Windows Installer rule collection is a set of rules created for Windows Installer file types (.mst, .msi and .msp) to allow you to control the installation of files on client computers and servers.

segment.source: Manage all software on the computer
segment.target: Manage all software on the computer

segment.source: All software is managed in one rule set.
segment.target: All software is managed in one rule set.

segment.source: By default, the policy for managing all software on a device disallows all software on the user's device, except software that is installed in the Windows folder, Program Files folder, or subfolders.
segment.target: By default, the policy for managing all software on a device disallows all software on the user's device, except software that is installed in the Windows folder, Program Files folder, or subfolders.

segment.source: Unlike SRP, each AppLocker rule collection functions as an allowed list of files.
segment.target: Unlike SRP, each AppLocker rule collection functions as an allowed list of files.

segment.source: Only the files that are listed within the rule collection will be allowed to run.
segment.target: Only the files that are listed within the rule collection will be allowed to run.

segment.source: This configuration makes it easier for administrators to determine what will occur when an AppLocker rule is applied.
segment.target: This configuration makes it easier for administrators to determine what will occur when an AppLocker rule is applied.

segment.source: Rules are applied uniformly to all users on a particular device.
segment.target: Rules are applied uniformly to all users on a particular device.

segment.source: On a device that is shared by multiple users, an administrator can specify the groups of users who can access the installed software.
segment.target: On a device that is shared by multiple users, an administrator can specify the groups of users who can access the installed software.

segment.source: Using AppLocker, an administrator can specify the user to whom a specific rule should apply.
segment.target: Using AppLocker, an administrator can specify the user to whom a specific rule should apply.
